Comment: A new episode of *Economics, Applied* asks why America has so many homicides involving firearms each year. Host [Steven J. Davis](https://www.hoover.org/profiles/steven-j-davis) speaks to Jens Ludwig about his deeply researched new book on gun deaths in America. Professor Ludwig teaches at the University of Chicago’s Harris School of Public Policy and serves as director of the University’s Crime Lab, as well as co-director of the National Bureau of Economic Research’s working group on the economics of crime. Davis and Ludwig discuss why America has so many gun deaths, how traditional narratives fail to explain most gun violence, and why past policies failed to reduce the deadly toll. Ludwig advances a fuller explanation for gun violence, grounded in evidence and behavioral insights, building on the arguments in his 2025 book, [*Unforgiving Places: The Unexpected Origins of American Gun Violence*](https://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/U/bo244203115.html).
